metadata.title: Bacterial cellulose nanocomposites_ An all-nano type of material

sections.text:
Contents lists available at ScienceDirect
Materials Science & Engineering C
journal homepage: www.elsevier.com/locate/msec
Review
Bacterial cellulose nanocomposites: An all-nano type of material
F.G. Torres⁎, J.J. Arroyo, O.P. Troncoso Department of Mechanical Engineering, Pontificia Universidad Católica del Perú (Lima 32 Perú), Av. Universitaria 1801, Lima 32, Lima, Peru
A R T I C L E I N F O
Keywords: Bacterial cellulose All-nano composites Undisturbed bacterial cellulose network Bacterial cellulose applications
A B S T R A C T
Bacterial cellulose (BC) is a fascinating polymer with a three-dimensional structure formed by nanofibers of pure cellulose, synthesized by some bacteria and organized as a coherent network. Its biocompatibility and remarkable mechanical properties have promoted scientific interest for its use in a variety of applications including biomedical, electrical, among others. However, it is the possibility of incorporating nanosized materials into the coherent 3-D network structure displayed by BC what has propelled multiple investigations on the development of BC nanocomposites for different applications. Here we report the different methods and techniques used so far for the BC nanocomposites production. We have focused on the processing techniques that allow the incorporation of functional nanoreinforcements, nanofillers and additional phases without disturbing the original network structure, leading to the formation of nanomaterials. Processing methods, resulting structure-property relationships and potential applications of these novel nanocomposites are discussed and showcased as a fair example of integrated design and manufacture of materials.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
Manufacturing companies, government agencies at all levels and consumers increasingly require the use of biodegradable materials, in order to reduce the environmental impact generated by the current lifestyle. Natural cellulose-based materials (which are the most abundant polysaccharides in nature [1–3] and include wood, hemp, cotton, among others) have been used for a long time by our society for these applications due to their wide availability, renewability, and biodegradability. Along the same lines, the study and use of bacterial cellulose is relatively recent. Despite sharing a common backbone, there are marked differences between plant and bacterial cellulose. Plant fibers are composed of lignin, hemicelluloses, pectin and only 40–70% of cellulose [4]; in contrast, bacterial cellulose is made up of pure cellulose nanofibers, displaying high purity and strength, without requiring subsequent refining treatments. Owing to these unique characteristics, bacterial cellulose (BC) has been extensively studied and characterized [5–8].
BC is a material synthesized extracellularly by certain types of bacteria such as Acetobacter, Azotobacter, Gluconacetobacter, Pseudomonas, Salmonella and Sarcina ventriculi [6]. Among them, the most effective and, thus, the most used bacteria for cellulose production are Gluconacetobacter xylinum, Gluconacetobacter hansenii, and Gluconacetobacter pasteurianus [9]. According to Czaja et al. [10], cellulose biosynthesis starts when bacteria polymerize glucose residues into
linear β-1,4-glucan chains and produce an extracellular secretion of the formed chains. Last, they assemble and crystallize the chains into composed ribbons. This process leads to the formation of a coherent ultra-thin three-dimensional network of cellulose nanofibers aligned in parallel to the surface of a liquid medium (see Fig. 1). This network is called a pellicle and its geometry is determined by intra- and intermolecular hydrogen-bonding network, hydrophobic and van der Waals interactions [11].
BC has a crystallographic structure typical of cellulose type Iα [12], with a degree of crystallinity up to 90% [13]. The several hydroxyl groups on BC surface make it a hydrophilic material [14]. BC nanofibers are around 20–100 nm in diameter and display a surface area superior to that of vegetal cellulose [15]. Grande et al. [16] analyzed the mechanical properties of BC films, yielding an average tensile strength of 241.42 ± 21.86MPa, a maximum elongation value of 8.21 ± 3.01% and Young's modulus of 6.86 ± 0.32 GPa.
The functionality, flexibility and excellent mechanical properties of bacterial cellulose have been considered adequate for certain applications in the past. However, the contemporary need for BC-based products with superior properties to meet the demand in diverse fields becomes increasingly evident. Modern BC-based composites involve the use of nanosized elements of particular characteristics. Since BC has a nanofibers arrangement, the developed materials consist of the interaction of two nanometric structures, which we call nano-nano composites.
