T
Here we review a variety of studies regarding the processing techniques that allow the incorporation of functional nanoreinforcements, nanofillers, and additional phases into bacterial cellulose, with a particular interest on those produced without disturbing the original BC network structure. The nanomaterials used for the preparation of BCbased nanocomposites are reviewed, including conducting polymers [17,18], graphene oxide [19,20], carbon nanotubes [21], ceramics [22,23] and biopolymers [24,25]. We also explain how the addition of these nanomaterials improve the electrical, optical and mechanical properties of BC, enabling its application in acoustic diaphragms [26], supercapacitors and biosensors [27], and biomedical applications [28–30]. A systematic classification of the BC-based materials is proposed, taking into account i) the BC fiber network final state (destroyed or preserved), and ii) the technique used to incorporate the second phase.

sections.heading: 2. Materials used for the preparation of bacterial cellulose nanocomposites
sections.text:
It is indeed the ability to incorporate other materials into the coherent BC network structure what has allowed for the development of a variety of nanocomposites for multiple applications. In this section, we review the different types of materials that have been used so far in BC nanocomposites formation.
2.1. BC nanofibrils as reinforcing fillers
Bacterial cellulose can be used as a reinforcement of nanoscale dimensions, whereas the micrometer-scale diameter of polymer fibers can act as a substrate for BC attachment. Juntaro et al. [31] developed a process to cover sisal fibers with BC. They used these BC-covered sisal fibers to reinforce a poly-L-lactic acid (PLA) matrix. First, they added the sisal fibers (tensile strength and Young's modulus of 383MPa and 15.2 GPa, respectively) to the BC growth medium. After 4–7 days of incubation a transparent BC pellicle covered the sisal fibers. The fiber pull-out tests showed that the interfacial adhesion of the BC-covered sisal fibers was increased. The elastic modulus and tensile strength of the BC/PLA composites was higher when the BC-covered sisal fibers were used (11.21 GPa and 113.8MPa, respectively, in contrast to 7.91 GPa and 78.9MPa). Pommet et al. [32] used a similar procedure to incorporate bacterial cellulose-modified sisal fibers into cellulose acetate butyrate matrices, reporting a significant improvement of interfacial adhesion and mechanical performance. Lee et al. [33] used acrylated epoxidised soybean oil (AESO) to develop sisal fiber/polyAESO and BC-sisal fiber/polyAESO composites. The tensile modulus for neat polyAESO was 0.4 GPa. The addition of 40 vol% sisal fibers improved the tensile modulus to 3.2 GPa, and further improvement was achieved with BC used as a binder, up to 5.6 GPa. Bacterial cellulose nanofibers were used as a filler for glass-fiber-reinforced epoxy composites [34]. By the incorporation of 0.3 wt% BC nanofibers, the interlaminar fracture toughness for crack initiation and crack separation
were improved by 128.8% and 1110%, respectively. Phomrak et al. [35] developed natural rubber composites reinforced with BC via a latex aqueous microdispersion process. The hydrophilicity, opacity, and crystallinity of the composite were improved by incremental BC loading. The reinforcement with BC nanofibers yields a material with 4128.4MPa of Young's modulus and tensile strength of 75.1MPa. At lower BC nanofibers reinforcement, the material presented high elastic elongation, which may be suitable for rubber-based products and elastic packaging.

sections.heading: 2.2. Conductive polymers
sections.text: The discovery of the high conductivity of polyacetylene [36] opened a highly explored path of conductive polymers. These are a family of highly conjugated polymers with spatially extended π-bonding, which present unique electrical, electrochemical and optical properties [37]. The aim of incorporating conductive polymers into BC is to develop flexible nanocomposites that can be used as electrolytes or stimuli-responsive membranes in solar energy devices, biosensors and biomedical devices. Among the most used conductive polymers are polyaniline (PAni), polypyrrole (PPY), poly(3,4-ethylene dioxythiophene) (PEDOT) and poly(p-phenylene vinylene) (PPV).

sections.heading: 2.2.1. Polyaniline
sections.text: Polyaniline belongs to the semi-flexible rod polymer family, which are organic polymers transformed into conductive polymers through oxidation or doping mechanisms [38]. Wang et al. [39] developed BCsupported polyaniline by in situ polymerization of aniline onto the BC matrix. The nanocomposite displayed an electrical conductivity of 5.1 S cm−1 and a mass capacitance of 273 F·g−1 at 0.2 A·g−1. Marins et al. [40] added polyaniline doped with dodecylbenzene sulfonic acid by in situ chemical polymerization on hydrated BC sheets, which led to a conductivity of 2.09× 10−2 S cm−1. Müller et al. [18] followed a similar procedure, adding polyaniline through in situ oxidative chemical polymerization of BC films, with FeCl3·6H2O as oxidant and the presence of HCl in an aqueous solution. They reported a conductivity of 0.9 S cm−1, evidencing that the crystalline structure of BC remained intact and the electrical properties improved as the reaction time increased since it stimulated a more significant and complete coating. Likewise, Hu et al. [17] performed an in situ oxidative polymerization of PAni, improving the thermal stability and finding a conductivity of 5× 10−2 S cm−1 for a PAni content of 10.7 wt% and a reaction time of 90min. Moreover, the mechanical measurements gave a Young's modulus value of 5.6 GPa and a tensile strength of 95.7MPa, being superior to pristine BC characteristics. Recently, Wan et al. [41] developed a flexible BC/graphene/PAni by uniform dispersion of graphene on the BC matrix and a subsequent PAni deposition on the surfaces of graphene layers and BC fibers. They reported an electrical conductivity of 1.7 S cm−1.

sections.heading: 2.2.2. Polypyrrole
sections.text: Polypyrrole is another organic polymer formed by the polymerization of pyrrole. PPy and its derivatives exhibit excellent properties, such as good environmental stability, electrical conductivity, high energy density, and ease to synthesize [42]. Li et al. [43] formed highly conductive paper electrodes using bacterial cellulose–polypyrrole nanofibers filled with multi-walled carbon nanotubes. The paper electrodes presented a stable and efficient performance, with a capacitance of 2.43 F cm−2. Similarly, Peng et al. [44] deposited polypyrrole and nickel sulfide on BC fibrous membranes, reporting a conductivity of 5.1 S cm−1, a specific capacitance of 713 F·g−1 and an energy density of 239Wh kg−1 at a current density from 0.2 to 1.6 mA cm−2. Müller et al. [45] performed an in situ polymerization of pyrrole (Py) in a BC film using ammonium persulfate (APS) and FeCl3·6H2O as oxidants. BC/PPyAPS presented homogeneously distributed spherical conductive nanoparticles, while BC/PPy-FeCl3 revealed the formation of a continuous conductive layer that covered BC nanofibers. After analyzing the mechanical and electrical properties of the BC/PPy nanocomposites, they reported a conductivity of 2.7 S cm−1 and tensile strength of 4.1 MPa when FeCl3·6H2O was the oxidant agent. Lay et al. [42] performed the in situ polymerization of pyrrole on BC, using FeCl3. The BC/PPy membrane acquired a conductivity of 3.9 S cm−1 and a specific capacitance of 191 F·g−1, which could be fully implemented in biomedical sensors and energy storage devices.

sections.heading: 2.2.3. PEDOT
sections.text: Developed by the Bayer AG® research laboratories in Germany [46], poly(3,4-ethylene dioxythiophene) or simply known as PEDOT is an insoluble polymer, with interesting characteristics such as high conductivity, transparency in thin and oxidized films, and high stability in the oxidized state [47]. In order to make PEDOT processable, poly (styrene sulfonic acid) is used as dopant. PSS reduces the conductivity of PEDOT from 300 S cm−1 to 10 S cm−1, but PEDOT:PSS samples display high visible light transmissivity and great stability [48]. Khan et al. [49] carried out the ex situ incorporation of commercial poly(3,4ethylene dioxythiophene)-poly(styrene sulfonate) (PEDOT:PSS) polymer into BC pellicles. The BC/PEDOT:PSS nanocomposites displayed a conductivity of 12.17 S cm−1, which is one of the highest values obtained for BC-based nanocomposites. Kim et al. [50] deposited PEDOT:PSS conductive layers on the top and bottom of a BC film by dipping and drying it, forming electro-active hybrid actuators. Aleshin et al. [51] synthesized BC/PEDOT:PSS, which presented a strong absorption near the infrared spectral region, with a potential application in the development of biocompatible electrodes. Bu et al. [52] evenly coated the surface of BC fibers with PEDOT, forming an ultrathin flexible paper electrode, which displayed a volumetric capacitance of 106.3 F cm−3 at a volumetric current density of 0.83 A cm−3.

sections.heading: 2.2.4. Polyphenylene vinylene
sections.text: The first polymer light-emitting device was based on poly(p-phenylene vinylene) or also named polyphenylene vinylene [53], which is a highly stable conjugated polymer. Aleshin et al. [54] built up a flexible light-emitting transparent paper based on bacterial cellulose. They saturated a BC film with MEH-PPV (poly[2-methoxy-5-(2-ethylhexyloxy)-1,4-phenylene]vinylene) by dipping the BC film in a MEHPPV/chloroform solution for 15 h. The photo-luminescence spectroscopy tests showed that the photoluminescence spectrum of BC/ MEH:PPV films contained emission contributions from both BC and MEH:PPV. This result suggests that BC/MEH:PPV nanocomposites could be used for the production of transparent light-emitting papers for display, lighting and biosensor devices.

sections.heading: 2.3. Metals
sections.text:
A different approach to enhance the properties of BC nanocomposites is the use of metallic nanoparticles. These inorganic materials can
be associated with the hydrophilic bacterial cellulose matrix, occupying its void spaces and interacting with BC fiber chains [37]. Due to their size and the surface effects, they allow adjusting the properties of the final nanocomposite. Some of the metal nanoparticles used in the past for BC nanocomposites include iron, silver, gold, copper, palladium and metal alloys, among others.
Zhang et al. [55] used magnetite (Fe3O4) nanoparticles to reinforce BC through in situ synthesis of Fe3O4, developing a flexible magnetic membrane. They achieved a homogeneous distribution of magnetite over the matrix. Zhu et al. [56] employed Fe3O4 as an adsorbent for heavy metal ions, reporting a high adsorption capacity and recyclability after ions elution. Sriplai et al. [57] fabricated magnetic BC composites by immersing a freeze-dried scaffold into a water-based ferrofluid containing Fe3O4 magnetic nanoparticles. Their sensitivity to external magnetic forces opens a nearly exhaustless potential of possible applications.
Silver and its derivatives exhibit strong inhibitory and bactericidal effects [58–60] and have been used for many biomedical applications [61,62]. Maneerung et al. [58] immersed a BC film into a silver nitrate solution. Then, sodium borohydride was used to reduce the incorporated Ag+ into metallic silver nanoparticles. The results showed strong antimicrobial activity of the BC/silver films against Escherichia coli and Staphylococcus aureus. Wu et al. [63] developed a novel method to perform an in-situ synthesis of Ag nanoparticles on BC membranes. BC membranes were soaked in a silver ammonia solution (Tollen's reagent). The guest molecules of Tollens' reagent diffused into the inner spaces of BC nanopores and reacted with cellulose fibers, forming an AgNP-BC composite. The results showed a strong interaction between the silver nanoparticles and BC fibers, which prevented the drop of Ag nanoparticles from the BC network, minimizing toxic effects. AgNP-BC exhibited significant antibacterial activities with more than 99% reductions in Escherichia coli, Staphylococcus aureus and Pseudomonas aeruginosa.
Gold nanoparticles receive the attention of researchers due to their outstanding optical, electronic, and chemical properties [64]. BC/Au nanocomposites have been used as catalyst [65–67], trace concentration detection [68] and biosensors devices [69]. Zhang et al. [69] reduced HAuCl4 with polyethyleneimine (PEI, a reducing agent) in a solution to obtain Au nanoparticles in aqueous dispersion. The authors uniformly coated BC nanofibers using the nanoparticle suspension, considering the PEI role as a linking agent. Subsequently, a biosensor was developed by embedding horseradish peroxidase (HRP) in the structure of the BC/Au nanocomposite, which displayed a high sensitivity detection of H2O2. Liu et al. [70] elaborated conductive cellulose films by a self-assembly procedure, using an aqueous gold dispersion of nanoparticles. The films displayed an electrical conductive behavior when the gold nanoparticle loading was higher than 20wt%.
Peng et al. [71] used BC covered with polypyrrole/copper oxide to prepare a conductive membrane. The BC/polypyrrole/copper oxide membrane had an electrical conductivity of 7.4 S cm−1 and a capacitance of 601 F·g−1, being suitable for flexible energy-storage devices. Among other nanoparticles, Chen et al. [72] synthesized zinc oxide particles using a polyol method, to introduce Zn2+ ions. Peng et al. [44] coated the BC membrane with polypyrrole/nickel sulfide, achieving a conductivity of 5.1 S cm−1. Yang et al. [73] carried out the in situ deposition of Pt nanoparticles on BC, finding that the BC/Pt membrane presented a high electrocatalytic activity in the hydrogen oxidation reaction.
BC films were immersed in a mixture solution of PdCl2 and CuCl2 in water. The adsorbed metallic ions were reduced inside the BC matrix to Pd-Cu nanoparticles using potassium borohydride, obtaining a composite with high catalytic activity [74]. Olsson et al. [75] developed a stiff magnetic nanopaper using bacterial cellulose fibrils as templates for ferromagnetic cobalt ferrite nanoparticles growth.

sections.heading: 2.4. Graphene and derivatives
sections.text: Several studies have reported the incorporation of two-dimensional reinforcements such as graphene, graphene oxide, reduced graphene oxide and carbon nanotubes [76–81] in BC, with the aim of improving the mechanical and electrical properties of pristine BC matrix.

sections.heading: 2.4.1. Graphene
sections.text: Graphene, the first two-dimensional atomic crystal available, presents outstanding mechanical stiffness, strength, high thermal and electrical conductivity [82], and a large specific surface area. The use of graphene and its derivatives could impressively enhance the inherent properties of BC. Luo et al. [79] dispersed graphene in the BC culture medium using a layer-by-layer interface culture strategy to obtain BC/ graphene nanocomposite hydrogels. The methodology consists of repetitive cycles of spraying the culture medium onto the base membrane until it is completely consumed. The BC/graphene hydrogels exhibited 91% improvement in tensile strength and 279% improvement in tensile modulus compared to pure BC. Zhou et al. [83] added graphite nanoplates to pristine BC membranes using two methods: immersion and sonication. The comparison showed a more significant increase in electrical conductivity for sonication (conductivity of 1.2 S cm−1). Shao et al. [84] crushed BC pellicles using a high speed homogenizer to achieve BC fiber slurry. Graphene aqueous solution was added into the BC homogenate and treated by ultrasonication followed by preparation of BC/graphene composite films. Results showed that graphene addition decreased the water retention capacity of BC, although the mechanical properties were enhanced in comparison to pure BC. These results are attributed to a uniform dispersion of graphene in the BC matrix, good miscibility and strong interfacial interactions between them [78].

sections.heading: 2.4.2. Graphene oxide
sections.text:
Graphene is a relatively new material with extraordinary mechanical and electrical properties. Graphene oxide (GO) in turn exhibits a high hydrophilic behavior, which enhances the formation of stable aqueous colloids and the assembly of macroscopic structures [85]. Feng et al. [76] developed BC/GO nanocomposites using an immersion technique, achieving a conductivity of 3.5× 10−2 S cm−1. Shao et al. [86] synthesized BC/GO by a sonochemical method. After its characterization against Escherichia coli and Staphylococcus aureus, they concluded that the composite presented excellent antibacterial activities. Liu et al. [87] developed a hybrid composite based on the chemical bonding of bacterial cellulose and graphene oxide coated with polypyrrole. The resultant material presented high electrical conductivity (1.32 S cm−1) and large volumetric capacitance (278 F cm−3). Luo et al. [88] used a layer-by-layer assembly strategy. A pure BC membrane was used as a base (named BC0). They added a GO suspension to the culture medium of BC, and the GO-dispersed culture medium was sprayed on the surface of BC0, building a BC/GO
membrane. Once the medium was consumed, the procedure was repeated, until the desired thickness was reached. The developed hydrogels presented improved mechanical properties in comparison with BC and previously reported BC/GO composites.
Graphene oxide has also been used in its reduced form. The reduced graphene oxide (RGO) formation can be carried out thermally [89,90], chemically [90–92] or by irradiation [93,94], enhancing the conductivity and partially recovering the original structure and properties of graphene [85]. Nandgaonkar et al. [95] prepared BC/RGO using a culture medium that allows synthesizing the fibers during their combination with RGO, reporting a conductivity of 2.37×10−1 S cm−1. Recently, Ccorahua et al. [20] also developed BC/RGO nanocomposites using an in situ hydrazine treatment, obtaining a conductivity of 12× 10−2 S cm−1.

sections.heading: 2.4.3. Carbon nanotubes
sections.text: Carbon nanotubes are allotropes of carbon, formed by graphene sheets wrapped in a nano-cylindrical tube. The addition of small amounts of carbon nanotubes to BC contributes to the improvement of the mechanical strength, electrical conductivity, and thermal conductivity [96]. Yoon et al. [97] prepared BC/multi-walled carbon nanotubes (MWCNTs) nanocomposites (Fig. 2). They used sodium dodecylbenzene sulfonate to disperse MWNTs in water and then immerse the BC film in the resulting solution. The reported conductivity was 4.2×10−1 S cm−1. Li et al. [98] incorporated MWCNT's and polyaniline in a BC membrane to prepare flexible electrodes for flexible supercapacitors. The BC/MWCNT/PAni electrodes had an excellent specific capacitance (656 F·g−1 at a discharge current density of 1 A·g−1) and remarkable cycling stability with capacitance degradation less than 0.5% after 1000 charge-discharge cycles (at a current density of 10 A·g−1).

sections.heading: 2.5. Ceramic
sections.text: Certain mineral elements such as hydroxyapatite, silica, and calcium carbonate have been investigated for biomedical applications, due to their biocompatible, non-toxic and hard tissue-mimicking nature. Ceramic nanoclays stand out for their mechanical reinforcing capability.

sections.heading: 2.5.1. Hydroxyapatite
sections.text:
Hydroxyapatite (HAp) is a phosphate mineral formed by calcium phosphate, commonly used in bone grafting [99,100], and bone drug delivery [101], which displays a structure and chemical composition similar to those of bone minerals. Grande et al. [23] prepared BC/HAp nanocomposites by introducing HAp in the culture medium. The resulting nanocomposites were found to be adequate for biomedical applications. Fig. 3(a) presents a schematic representation of the inclusion of HAp nanoparticles within the BC matrix. Fig. 3(b) shows the distribution of those nanoparticles in the BC 3-D network. Wan et al. [102]
phosphorylated BC for enhancing its capability to induce HAp formation. The results revealed that phosphorylation effectively triggered HAp formation compared with unphosphorylated BC. Zimmermann et al. [103] negatively charged BC with the adsorption of carboxymethyl cellulose (CMC) to initiate the nucleation of calcium-deficient hydroxyapatite (cdHAp). Saska et al. [104] developed nanocomposites by using BC membranes incubated in solutions of CaCl2 followed by Na2HPO4. The nanocomposites were effective for bone defect regeneration in rat tibiae. Hutchens et al. [105] deposited cdHAp in a bacterial cellulose hydrogel in order to prepare a composite mimicking the natural biomineralization of bone.

sections.heading: 2.5.2. Silica
sections.text: Silica is the major component of sand, obtained by sand mining and purification of quartz. Yano et al. [106] prepared nanocomposites of BC filled with silica (SiO2) following two methods: silica addition to the culture medium and BC hydrogels immersion. Maeda et al. [107] developed a BC/silica hybrid through immersion and posterior hot pressing, obtaining an improved Young's modulus and tensile strength of 17 GPa and 185MPa, respectively. BC/silica nanocomposites have been proposed as aerogels [108], light emitting silicon-based materials [109] and adsorbents for water purification [110].

sections.heading: 2.5.3. Calcium carbonate
sections.text: Calcium carbonate (CaCO3) is frequently found in rocks as calcite and aragonite minerals. It is also found in mineralized tissues of biological systems [111]. Besides the use of BC as a template for HAp addition, CaCO3 can be placed inside a BC matrix pores [112–114]. Stoica-Guzun et al. [111] investigated the effect of sonication of CaCO3 on a BC membrane, using CaCl2 and Na2CO3 as reactants. They found that ultrasound irradiation originated bigger crystals with a large variety of shapes in comparison to crystals of non-irradiated samples. Later, Stoica-Guzun et al. [115] tested the effect of microwave irradiation, using the same reactants as in their previous work. The results showed notorious differences between morphology and polymorphism of irradiated calcium carbonate crystals, with presumably medical and industrial applications.

sections.heading: 2.5.4. Nanoclays
sections.text:
Some studies have shown that the dispersion of nanoclays in a polymeric matrix improves its mechanical and barrier properties, its thermal stability and biodegradability [116–119], which are dependent on the interaction between the matrix and the nanoclays. Perotti et al. [120] developed BC/laponite clay nanocomposites at different ratios by coating a BC film with a dispersion of clay particles in water. They obtained a significant degree of adhesion that improved the Young's modulus and tensile strength. Ul-Islam et al. [22] incorporated
montmorillonite at different concentrations in a BC matrix. They assessed the antibacterial activities of BC-based films against Escherichia coli and Staphylococcus aureus, showing an excellent response at a high montmorillonite concentration.

sections.heading: 2.6.1. Collagen
sections.text: Collagen is a natural biopolymer that forms fibers in several animal tissues and organs. Despite its huge flexibility, collagen displays a high tensile strength, which has motivated its application in the biomedical field. Zhijiang and Guang [121] immersed BC in a solution of collagen in acetic acid and then filtered the collagen excess. After filtration, the material was freeze-dried. The crystalline structure remained unchanged, although the thermal stability improved. Besides, Young's modulus and tensile strength increased, which makes the composite suitable for wound dressing. Saska et al. [122] modified BC by glycine esterification in order to crosslink it with type I collagen. The nanocomposite possessed a more flexible structure, which makes it easy to handle during surgical procedures. Luo et al. [123] prepared BC/collagen nanocomposites by adding collagen to the BC culture medium. BC reduced its porosity and roughness after collagen incorporation. The results showed changes in the crystallinity, color, and thickness of the BC/collagen films in comparison to pure BC.

sections.heading: 2.6.2. Chitosan
sections.text:
Chitosan presents interesting properties such as exudes absorption, antimicrobial and wound-healing characteristics. Ul-Islam et al. [124] immersed BC sheets in a 1% acetic acid solution in which 1% of chitosan was dissolved, monitoring the chitosan adsorption at various temperatures and treatment time. They reported an enhancement of mechanical properties, water holding capacity and water release rate at 50 °C in a shaking operation mode, which may lead to its use in biomedical applications. Phisalaphong et al. [125] added low-molecularweight chitosan into the BC culture medium. The BC/chitosan nanocomposite prepared had smaller pores compared to pristine BC showing high mechanical properties in the wet and dry state, high water absorption capacity and high average surface area. Cai et al. [126] immersed a BC wet pellicle in a solution of chitosan in acetic acid. The chitosan molecules penetrated the BC structure, forming a multi-layer network with great thermal stability (thermal degradation temperature changed from 263 °C to 366 °C when chitosan content increased from 1.2% to 4.5%) and reduced tensile strength and Young's modulus. A similar procedure was followed by Kim et al. [127]. They developed BC/chitosan nanocomposites via BC immersion in a chitosan solution followed by a freeze-drying step. The incorporation of chitosan in the BC matrix results in a decrease in the degree of crystalline of BC and an
improvement in thermal stability and biocompatibility with almost unchanged mechanical properties. Lin et al. [128] also produced BC/ chitosan nanocomposites by immersing BC films into a chitosan solution. They reported that the BC/chitosan nanocomposites prepared retain moisture in time without dehydration and inhibit bacterial growth. They used the BC/nanocomposites as wound dressings and found faster wound regeneration in comparison to pure BC dressings.

sections.heading: 2.6.3. Gelatin and starch
sections.text: Other biopolymers that interact with BC for the development of nanocomposites are gelatin and starch. Nakayama et al. [129] synthesized BC/gelatin by immersing a BC film in an aqueous solution of gelatin. Despite the poor mechanical characteristics of gelatin, BC/gelatin double network gels can sustain almost 3MPa and display an elastic modulus of 23MPa, 112 times higher than the elastic modulus of gelatin. Grande et al. [24] developed a self-assembling procedure to incorporate starch into a BC matrix (Fig. 4). They added starch to the growth medium and autoclaved it, which induced the gelatinization of starch. The bacteria synthesized BC fibers in the presence of the partially gelatinized starch granules. With this bottom-up process, starch was incorporated into the BC network maintaining the crystallinity degree of native BC with a smooth decrease in the mechanical properties. Wan et al. [130] incorporated plasticized starch to BC nanofibers. Starch and glycerin were mixed (30% w/w glycerin to starch), and later the BC membrane was immersed in the solution. The BC/starch nanocomposite displayed a superior tensile strength and modulus than starch, but a lower elongation at break.

sections.heading: 2.7. Nano-nano structures
sections.text:
The supra-molecular (“all-nano”) architecture of bacterial cellulose, characterized by its loose fibril arrangement, high aspect ratio, high surface area per unit mass [131] and a reactive surface due to OH side groups, provides BC with a tendency to form intra- and intermolecular bonding [132] (hydrogen bonds or van der Waals forces) and grafting of chemical species to achieve surface functionalization. This behavior favored the development of BC nanocomposites through self-assembly [24], matrix irradiation [133], controlled dispersions within matrix polymers and controlled particle-matrix bond strength [134].
As emphasized throughout this section, the main characteristic of the BC matrix is that, instead of being a concentrated structure of
molecules, it has a nanofibers arrangement. Therefore, it can be considered as a supra-molecular structure of nanometric dimensions. Since most of the dispersed phases also present a nanometric scale size, the majority of BC nanocomposites are formed from the interaction of two nanometric supra-molecular structures. In that sense, considering the components that lead to the formation of BC nanocomposites (see classification diagram in Fig. 5), the generated material should be adequately denominated a nano-nano composite.

sections.heading: 3. Processing methods used for the production of bacterial cellulose nanocomposites
sections.text:
Numerous methods have been developed to produce nano-nano composites based on BC, with the aim of achieving a correct dispersion of the nanofillers in the BC matrix, avoiding the formation of large aggregates. The use of a particular method depends on the nature of the combining phase and the envisaged application for the BC nanocomposites. In general, BC has been used as a matrix (to be loaded with nanofillers), or as a reinforcement. Thus, the classification we propose is based on the final state of the BC structure once the nano-nano
composite is obtained: i) disturbed or ii) undisturbed network, as illustrated in Figs. 6 and 7.

sections.heading: 3.1. Disturbed network
sections.text: There are three very well-known procedures by which the formation of BC nanocomposites is performed after modifying the original BC structure.

sections.heading: 3.1.1. BC disintegration
sections.text:
Gea et al. [25] developed nanocomposites by disintegrating a BC film and then mixing it with apple and radish pulp. The non-disintegrated BC presented a high tensile modulus (17 GPa), although after processing the value decreased to 8 GPa. In contrast, the biocomposite sheets with apple and radish pulp after BC reinforcement showed an improvement of 2 GPa in Young's modulus (from 4.5 GPa to 6.5 GPa). Feng et al. [76] prepared BC/GO composite by mixing GO and aqueous suspensions of disintegrated BC at fixed concentrations. The BC/GO mixture was then sonicated, filtered and dried for 24 h at 50 °C to form films. The films presented up to 20% of Young's modulus increase in comparison with pristine BC.
Nakagaito et al. [135] prepared BC/phenol-formaldehyde
nanocomposite films. The nanocomposite films were cut into pieces, stacked into layers of 25 sheets and hot-pressed. The Young's modulus of the nanocomposites was 28 GPa, higher than the modulus of pure BC sheets (19 GPa). They attributed the improvement to the uniform, continuous, and straight nano-scalar network of cellulosic elements oriented in-plane via the compression of BC film. Chiaoprakobkij et al. [136] formed a porous sponge from the blend of BC and sodium alginate. The BC pellicle was pressed and later mixed with sodium alginate at different weight ratios in distilled water. The slurry mixture was placed in Petri dishes and crosslinked with an aqueous CaCl2 solution. The composite exhibited a high mechanical strength, high water uptake ability, and structural stability. Amin et al. [137] combined lyophilized BC powder with acrylic acid (AAc) in an aqueous dispersion and subsequently exposed the mixture to accelerated electron-beam irradiation, forming BC/AAc hydrogels. The higher the amount of AAc in the gel, the higher the AAc degree of polymerization in polyacrylic acid (PAAc). In addition, those with a higher dose of radiation revealed a higher extracted weight and gel fraction, which suggests that a higher dose and a higher amount of AAc results in a highly crosslinked and insoluble network.

sections.heading: 3.1.2. Extraction of BC whiskers
sections.text:
A second approach for taking advantage of BC for the development of nanomaterials is to obtain BC whiskers [138–140]. BC whiskers are highly crystalline rod-like particles that are extracted by acid hydrolysis of bacterial cellulose microfibrils [141]. Their reinforcement ability lies in their high surface area and excellent mechanical properties [142,143]. Nevertheless, they should be well separated and distributed in the matrix [144].
It has been reported that the treatment of BC with acid [145,146] allowed extracting cellulose nanowhiskers effectively. Cellulose whiskers were incorporated into nanofibers of polyethylene oxide (PEO) by the electrospinning process to enhance the mechanical properties of the electrospun PEO fibers. The whiskers were partially aligned despite some aggregated areas. However, an increase in Young's modulus, tensile strength, and elongation at break was observed as the concentration increased [141]. Martínez-Sanz et al. [145] developed hybrid electrospun ethylene vinyl alcohol (copolymer) (EVOH) fibers reinforced with bacterial cellulose nanowhiskers. They incorporated BC nanowhiskers into 5% (w/v) EVOH solutions, generating hybrid fibers by electrospinning which presented an increase in the degree of crystallinity.

sections.heading: 3.1.3. Crosslinking
sections.text:
Crosslinking is a procedure that links one polymer chain to a chain of a different polymer, through covalent or ionic bonds. BC was crosslinked with fibrin in the presence of glutaraldehyde [147]. First, bovine fibrin was dissolved in a mixture of 1-butyl-3-methyl-imidazolium chloride (ionic liquid) and dimethyl sulfoxide. Then, the formation of the BC/fibrin membrane required the immersion of never-dried BC sheets in the fibrin solution. Later, the composites were immersed in glutaraldehyde solution at 80 °C. The action of glutaraldehyde promoted the crosslinking of hydroxyl groups of BC and the amide groups of fibrin, producing materials with similar tensile strength, modulus and time-dependent viscoelastic behavior compared with a small-diameter blood vessel. Castro et al. [148] have reported the crosslinking of the BC network via glyoxalization with glyoxal. The process started through medium modification using glyoxal, non-formaldehyde crosslinking agent. The process is started in situ, in the culture medium during biosynthesis of cellulose. This allowed the formation of covalent
bonds between glyoxal and BC ribbons, which caused an improvement in hydrophobicity. A similar approach was performed by Quero et al. [149]. Yang et al. [150] prepared a mixture of poly(vinyl alcohol) (PVA) powder and a BC suspension to produce BC/PVA hydrogels by crosslinking with formaldehyde. Tensile strength and Young's modulus were increased after chemical crosslinking took place.

sections.heading: 3.1.4. Bacterial cellulose derivatives based composites
sections.text:
Recent works have shown that the synthesis of different derivatives of BC by surface modification could open a great variety of potential applications. Several methods performing BC surface modification have been proposed, including but not limited to carboxymethylation, acetylation, alkylation, and sulfation. Acetylated bacterial cellulose is one of the most common BC derivatives used. The acetylation treatment replaces the hydroxyl groups of the unmodified BC by less hydrophilic acetyl groups, leading to an improvement in the thermal and moisture stability of BC-based materials. The optimization of the variables involved in the BC acetylation process such as reaction time, catalyst content and temperature allows tailoring the acetylation extent conferred to BC [151]. Goncalves et al. [152] extracted a subjacent lamina from the basement membrane of a porcine bladder (UBM). The digested UBM solution was used to coat acetylated bacterial cellulose (ABC), generating a moderate hydrophobic surface that was advantageous for retinal pigment epithelium cells adhesion and proliferation.
During carboxymethylation of BC, the cellulose hydroxyl groups are replaced by carboxyl groups, which promote the appearance of coordinate sites. Lin et al. [153] prepared a blend of carboxymethyl bacterial cellulose (CBC)/sodium alginate by an ionic crosslinking with Ca2+. The composite presented an improvement up to 152% in tensile strength, besides a marked improvement in swelling and thermal properties.
Lin et al. [154] carried out the first alkylation of BC, by etherification with alkyl bromide. Qin et al. [155] alkylated BC using alkyl halide in ionic liquid 1-butyl-3-methylimidazolium chloride and NaH as the base. The resultant derivatives have both hydrophilic and hydrophobic groups on their backbones, whose versatility may result advantageous for a wide variety of applications. Zhu et al. [156] characterized the properties of sulfated BC (SBC). They found that sulfation disrupts the crystalline structure of BC, which was reflected in a severe
degradation. The careful control of the moisture content in BC allowed to produce SBC with a high degree of substitution.

sections.heading: 3.2. Undisturbed network
sections.text: The importance of an undisturbed coherent fiber network structure on the mechanical and flow properties of polymer composites has been confirmed in the past for glass fiber composites [157,158]. Analogously, the purpose of the undisturbed network methods for BC-based materials development is to take advantage of the highly porous 3-D BC network for the formation of nanocomposites with enhanced properties. These methods can be further classified into two approaches: bottom-up and top-down.

sections.heading: 3.2.1. Top-down methods
sections.text:
3.2.1.1. In situ polymerization. In this process, suitable initiators, precursors, and monomers are dispersed in the BC network. Then, the initiators are exposed to an adequate source of excitation, such as heat or light. This exposition triggers the in-situ polymerization process that forms the nanocomposite. Müller et al. [159] developed BC/PPy nanocomposites through in-situ oxidative chemical polymerization. Dried BC membranes were immersed in pyrrole aqueous solution of pyrrole using FeCl3·6H2O as oxidant agent. Figueiredo et al. [160] performed an in situ radical polymerizations of 2-aminoethyl methacrylate, using N, N-methylene bis(acrylamide) as a crosslinker to obtain films of improved thermal and mechanical properties. Peng et al. [161] immersed BC membranes in a 1% styrene (St) solution with azobisisobutyronitrile (AIBN) as initiator. The immersed samples were pressed at 85 °C for 5 h to carry out the polymerization of the styrene monomers absorbed in the BC membranes. The BC/PS sheets showed superior mechanical properties compared to pure PS sheets. Choi et al. [162] used BC for the development of environmentally compatible ionexchange membranes. BC was immersed in benzophenone (BP) methanol solution, used as a photo-initiator, and then irradiated with UV light. An AAc solution was added to the activated BC membrane, to introduce ion-exchangeable groups. A methanol/acetone solution was used to thoroughly clean the resulting acrylic acid-treated bacterial cellulose (AAc-modified BC) membrane. The modified BC/AAc membrane acquired an ion-exchange capacity of 2.5meq·g−1 and greater structural density, as well as a tensile strength of 12MPa and 6.0% elongation. Also, Hu et al. [17] synthesized polyaniline/bacterial cellulose (BC/PAni) nanocomposites by in situ oxidative polymerization of aniline. The Young's modulus and tensile strength of BC decreased from 20 GPa and 357.3MPa to 5.6 GPa and 95.7MPa respectively after polyaniline addition. However, it increased the thermal stability of the flexible membrane and imparted the composite an electrical conductivity of 5× 10−2 S cm−1.
3.2.1.2. Matrix deposition. BC occurs naturally in the form of a threedimensional nanosized network with a highly porous structure. Matrix deposition consists of the diffusion of a filler solution into the BC matrix. The diffusion is achieved by immersing BC membranes in an aqueous solution of fillers or by injecting fillers that are soluble in water into the three-dimensional arrangement, forcing nanofillers to remain inside the pores through different bonding mechanisms. After evaporation of the solvent, the filler covers the surface of BC nanofibers and its internal pores. Later, it is dried or hot pressed to form a strong composite. Typically, matrix deposition is part of a larger and more complex procedure for nanocomposites formation. Kang et al. [163] developed all-solid-state flexible supercapacitors based on BC. A BC pellicle was pressed under 10MPa and later a carbon nanotubes (CNT) ink solution was poured onto the membrane.
Chen et al. [164] fabricated an asymmetric supercapacitor based on a 3D nanofibrous carbon network of bacterial cellulose pellicles by annealing for 2 h in an N2 atmosphere. Then, the films were immersed in a 0.1 M KMnO4/0.1M K2SO4 aqueous solution to obtain the
nanocomposites. This approach allowed developing a binder-free asymmetric supercapacitor, which delivers an energy density of 32.91W h kg−1 and a maximum power density of 284.63 kW kg−1. Yoon et al. [21] dispersed MWCNTs in a surfactant (cetyltrimethylammonium bromide) solution. Then, the BC films were dipped in the solution for different immersion rates. The authors reported a conductivity of 1.4× 10−4 S cm−1. Zhou et al. [83] dispersed MWCNTs in an absolute ethanol solution at 0.05 wt% concentration to coat the BC membrane. These membranes with 13.9 wt% MWCNT achieved a maximum electrical conductivity of 1.2 S cm−1. Considering a different nanofiller, Yano et al. [106] used silica sols to immerse BC hydrogel, allowing the particles to flow to the film and lodge in the spaces between the ribbon-shaped fibrils.
Legnani et al. [165] deposited ITO and SiO2 films onto dried BC membranes using radio frequency magnetron sputtering, to avoid heating of the substrate and thus minimization of the membrane strain. These materials can be used as a flexible organic optoelectronic device. Yang et al. [166] prepared BC/CdS hybrid nanofibers, which involves the immersion of BC fibers in ethanol and water (50:50 v/v). The next step consisted of the hydrothermal reaction of CdCl2 and ethanol-saturated BC fibers, and centrifugation leads to a uniform deposition of CdS nanoparticles, obtaining BC/CdS hybrid nanofibers. These nanofibers presented high efficiency as photocatalytic and good recyclability. Ccorahua et al. [20] presented a novel processing technique to incorporate GO into BC. Once the GO solution was poured over the BC gel, and a vacuum pump was turned on, GO was reduced by hydrazine, exposing the BC film to hydrazine vapors and forming a thin layer nanocomposite.

sections.heading: 3.2.2. Bottom-up methods
sections.text:
3.2.2.1. Incorporation of phases during BC synthesis. The addition of a second phase for the synthesis of BC fibers implies the modification of the growth medium. Some studies have reported that the inclusion of additives in the culture media promotes the formation of composites [167,168]. Saibuatong and Phisalaphong [169] added Aloe vera gel to the culture medium during biosynthesis. With the 30% v/v aloe gel supplement, the nanocomposite film displayed improved properties in mechanical strength, crystallinity, water absorption capacity, and water vapor permeability in contrast to unmodified BC films. Grande et al. [23] fabricated BC/HAp nanocomposites by incorporating a mineral phase in the static culture during the formation of cellulose microfibrils (Fig. 8). The resultant nanocomposite presented reduced crystallinity due to chemical bonds between the components that improve the chemical stabilization, and was found to be suitable for biomedical applications. Gea et al. [170] opted for the direct addition of PVA in an inoculated medium to prepare nanocomposites. The presence of PVA interrupted hydrogen bonding between cellulose fibrils, yielding a decrease in Young's modulus but an increase in ductility and work-offracture.
Grande et al. [24] prepared BC/starch (corn or potato) nanocomposites in the presence of partly gelatinized starch granules. This methodology takes advantage of the transport process occurring during a “smart” property of starch named gelatinization, which allows the self-assembly production of the nanocomposite. Starch was placed in the culture medium before a first gelatinization step (to control the diffusion of polymeric chains into BC network). Then, the BC nanofibrils grew in the presence of starch. A final hot pressing step permitted to obtain the BC/starch films.
The use of water-soluble cellulose derivatives such as methylcellulose and CMC enables the slight modification of the culture medium, resulting in a decreased crystallinity and crystal size, increased pore size and thermal stability. It is also known that increased pore volume and pore size via in situ modification lead to increased water holding capability and water release rate.
A different approach to incorporate a phase during the preparation of composites involves their elaboration through the fermentation of
Gluconacetobacter xylinus in a medium containing cell wall polysaccharides from the hemicellulose or pectin families [171]. It implies reviving and then culturing Gluconacetobacter xylinus in the presence of desired hemicelluloses and pectins.
3.2.2.2. Double-network hydrogels. Bacterial cellulose can be reinforced with activated monomers to synthesize double-network (DN) hydrogels. Nakayama et al. [129] immersed BC into a gelatin solution and then crosslinked the gelatin with N-(3-dimethyl-aminopropyl)-N′ethylcarbodiimide hydrochloride (EDC), which activates the carboxyl groups of amino acids. Finally, they obtained BC/gelatin DN gel, with a mechanical strength of several megapascals and a frictional coefficient of 10−3. Chang et al. [172] prepared double network hydrogels of BC and gelatin. Alkaline treated BC was crosslinked with gelatin using transglutaminase, genipin, and EDC as crosslinking agents. They found an improvement in both mechanical strength and hydrophilic properties of BC, given that gelatin filled the pores and connected the 3D structure of BC. Additionally, the increase in the concentration of gelatin enhanced the formation of double-network structures based on gelatin, which tends to improve the properties of the composite. Hagiwara et al. [173] developed BC/polyacrylamide (BC/PAAm) double network hydrogels using N,N′-methylene bisacrylamide as a crosslinker. The material presented a tensile fracture stress of 40 ± 10 KPa (similar to ligament strength, 38 ± 10 KPa), which suggest potential for the medical field.
Numata et al. [174] developed BC/PEG gels with high mechanical strength by forming a structure with crosslinked polyethylene glycol
diacrylate (PEGDA) polymer networks. The authors reported that the mechanical strength was dependent on the weight percent of crosslinked PEGDA in the gel, chain length between crosslinking points, and crosslinking density of PEGDA polymers, with fracture stress and elastic modulus up to 11.5 MPa and 12MPa, respectively. The thermo-responsiveness was preserved upon PEGDA addition, since the composite was opaque at low temperature and transparent at high temperature, as found for BC/PEG. Yasuda et al. [175] evaluated the properties of 4 double-network hydrogels, two of which were composed of BC: BC/ PDMAAm (polyacrylamide) and cellulose/gelatin. For the BC/ PDMAAm composite, the BC film was immersed in an aqueous solution of 3M DMAAm, which was polymerized in the presence of BC gel at 60 °C for 6 h. For BC/gelatin, BC was immersed in an aqueous solution of gelatin at 50 °C for one week and then immersed in 1-ethyl-(dimethylaminopropyl) carbodiimide for chemical crosslinking. BC/gelatin showed poor mechanical properties, while BC/PDMAAm resulted resistant to wear, superior in various degrees when compared with conventional hydrogels.

sections.heading: 4.1. Biomedical
sections.text:
In the same way as other polysaccharides were processed for biomedical applications [176], BC also found an area in which it can be harnessed [177–182]. Soft tissue mimicking materials are of high interest for the treatment of burns, ulcerative diseases or tissue
replacement. PVA is a hydrophilic biocompatible polymer with interesting characteristics. It can be crosslinked with BC to form a nanocomposite that exhibits improved lifespan, biocompatibility, and excellent mechanical properties. Millon and Wan [179] developed BC/ PVA nanocomposites and evaluated their capacity to replace cardiovascular tissues. They found that BC/PVA have similar characteristics to cardiovascular tissues. Wang et al. [183] used a freezing-thaw method to prepare a BC/PVA membrane as an artificial cornea replacement. The results showed that such BC/PVA nanocomposite had high water content, high visible light transmittance, UV absorbance, good mechanical properties, and thermal stability. An interesting application involves the formation of BC/polyethylene glycol (PEG) nanocomposites [184]. These BC/PEG nanocomposites showed improved thermal and mechanical properties due to their highly interconnected structure. In addition, they exhibited good cell adhesion and proliferation properties, making them suitable for tissue-engineering and wound dressing applications.
The combination of BC with different additives gives rise to materials that can be used for bone and cartilage tissue engineering. HAp and collagen make up natural bone. Then, given the outstanding osteoconductivity and bioactivity of HAp, it can be applied for tissue engineering in conjunction with BC [102]. Grande et al. [23] developed BC/HAp nanocomposites by introducing CMC and a mineral phase in the culture medium. The CMC addition caused a 50% reduction in the diameter of fibers. The authors demonstrated the biocompatibility and cell viability of the developed nanocomposite using HEK cell cultures. Saska et al. [122] proposed the combination of collagen and BC, forming flexible membranes which showed osteoblastic differentiation in vitro. Palaninathan et al. [185] functionalized BC by acetosulfation, verifying cell viability, antioxidant properties, and hemocompatibility of the as-constructed composite.
The BC nanosized network structure can be used as a starting point for specific tasks such as bone regeneration, which require a scaffold with microsized pores. To address this problem, Bäckdahl et al. [186] placed porogen materials like paraffin wax spheres and starch of various grain sizes in the growing medium of Acetobacter xylinum. They reported that smooth muscle cells migrated to the samples with larger pores diameter. Zaborowska et al. [187] incorporated 300–500 μm paraffin wax microspheres into the BC medium to improve cell infiltration, by increasing the pore size and introducing osteoprogenitor cells (Fig. 9). Such a scaffold may be of interest for bone regeneration, and it could facilitate osteoblast ingrowth and the formation of mineralized tissue.
A variety of natural and synthetic polymers are being developed, containing drug, growth factors, peptides, and other bioactive substances to enhance wound recovery [188]. In particular, the use of BC as a wound dressing has shown that BC-based dressings prevent moisture from evaporating and allow for drugs or other bioactive substances to maintain intimate contact with the injured area [189].
These properties can be achieved by modifying the specific characteristics of BC through structural changes, chemical reactions or simply the incorporation of a second phase [190]. BC nanocomposites have also been used as drug delivery systems. For instance, a dry BC film immersed in benzalkonium chloride (an antimicrobial agent) achieved a drug loading capacity of 0.116mg/cm2. Trials showed that the drug effects lasted for at least 24 h against contaminated wound flora (Staphylococcus aureus and Bacillus subtilis) [177]. Almeida et al. [191] doped BC membranes with glycerin for topical and transdermal drug delivery applications. The glycerin presence provided a skin moisturizing effect, useful for lesions with dryness such as psoriasis and atopic dermatitis.
Hydroxypropyl methylcellulose (HPMC) is a well-known tablet excipient [192]. Thus, a BC/HPMC composite has been produced adding HPMC to the culture medium. The trials for using BC based nanocomposites as tablet excipients show promising results, suggesting that BC can be used for the delivery of small drug molecules. To complement this point, BC seems to be an ideal base material due to its capacity to retain water. Müller et al. [193] grafted BC with polyacrylic acid for drug delivery system. The composite showed a pH-sensitive release of BSA (bovine serum albumin, a model protein) at intestinal pH. Besides, those samples with larger pores charged more BSA.

sections.heading: 4.2. Preparation of high strength nanocomposites
sections.text:
BC has been used as a binder in papers. The small clusters of BC fibers improve strength and durability of pulp paper [194], being viable to develop high strength paper. Nakagaito et al. [135] developed highstrength composites based on bacterial cellulose sheets, by impregnating these with phenolic resin and the use of a compression force of 100MPa. This process produced materials with a bending strength of 425MPa and Young's modulus of 28 GPa. The bidimensional orientation of the nano-scale BC network structure can be accounted for these high mechanical properties.
Additionally, bacterial cellulose has been used in the development of acoustic membranes. Acoustic transducer diaphragms require high stiffness and low density to maximize the velocity of sound through them. The extremely high Young's modulus and low density that characterizes BC allow the BC-based diaphragms to reach a sound velocity of approximately 5000m/s [195]. In 1988, the Sony Corporation developed the first audio speaker diagrams, based on the use of bacterial cellulose (see U.S. Patent 4,742,164).

sections.heading: 4.3. High adsorption composites
sections.text:
The highly porous structure of BC provides BC-based nanocomposites with high adsorption capabilities. This property can be useful for the removal of toxic components from certain elements, such as heavy metals from wastewater. Stoica-Guzun et al. [196] synthesized bacterial
cellulose-magnetite composites for the removal of chromium (VI) at different conditions (initial ions concentration, solution pH and solid/ liquid ratio upon ions removal) from aqueous solutions. The highest Cr (VI) removal efficiency was observed at pH 4. Chen et al. [197] formed CBC by incorporating a second phase in the culture medium. The composite exhibited good adsorption performance at pH 4.5, reaching the adsorption equilibrium within 1 h. The maximum adsorption capacity for copper and lead ions was 12.63 and 60.42mg/g, respectively. Zhu et al. [56] proposed BC/Fe3O4 nanocomposite for the adsorption of Pb2+, Mn2+, and Cr3+. The adsorption of Pb2+, Mn2+ and Cr3+ approaches 52mg/g, 26mg/g and 20mg/g, respectively for a heavy metals ion concentration of 200mg/l. Lu et al. [198] prepared a new adsorbent for Cr(VI) removal, ammonium sulfamate-bacterial cellulose (ASBC). The composite had as main adsorption mechanisms coordination adsorption and ion exchange, reporting good adsorption capacities at low pH (1–2), up to 23mg/g. The effective desorption of Cr(VI) reported by the authors also makes the composite reusable. Yang et al. [199] prepared BC/poly(m-phenylenediamine) (PmPD) composites for chromium removal. They performed the BC fibrils functionalization by mPD in-situ oxidative polymerization. The membranes had an adsorption capacity of 434.78mg/g. Oshima et al. [200] proposed the use of phosphorylated bacterial cellulose as an adsorbent of metal ions. Shen et al. [201] prepared BC/diethylenetriamine nanocomposites as membranes for Cu2+ and Pb2+ adsorption. The adsorption observed was a fast process which reached the adsorption equilibrium within 2 h. The adsorption kinetics closely followed the pseudo-second-order kinetic model, indicating the importance of chemical adsorption in the process. The nanocomposite presented the best adsorption capability at a pH of 4.5, with 63.09 and 87.41mg/g for Cu and Pb respectively.

sections.heading: 4.4. Optical materials
sections.text:
Optical materials need to have good transparency, good flexibility, dimensional stability, and be free from scattering. Nanostructures with components less than 1/10 of wavelength in size will not present scattering [202]. Thus, nanocomposites based on BC with fibers diameter in the range 40–70 nm, will display excellent optical properties, good flexibility, and dimensional stability [203]. Yano et al. [204] impregnated dried BC membranes with acrylic resin. The resulting nanocomposite had a fiber content of up to 70% and showed a small loss of transparency (less than 10%), significantly low thermal expansion coefficient and good mechanical properties compared with engineering plastics. Nogi et al. [205] prepared BC/tricyclodecane dimethanol dimethacrylate (TCDDMA) nanocomposites with different percentages of BC. They reported that the addition of 7.4 wt% of bacterial cellulose nanofibers caused light transmittance deterioration of only 2.4% but reduced the coefficient of thermal expansion of acrylic resin from 86×10−6 to 38×10−6 K−1.
BC nanofibers were acetylated to enhance the properties of optically transparent composites of acrylic resin reinforced with the nanofibers [206]. They found that acetylation reduced the refractive index of BC and the loss in regular transmittance of the material (from 13% to 3.4% at a fiber content of 63%). It also reduced hygroscopicity, and water absorption was found to be less than 0.5%. Besides, the coefficient of thermal expansion obtained was around 1×10−6 K−1. Later, Fernandes et al. [207] developed films based on BC and chitosan, obtaining a material with a transmittance of 90% in the range of 400–700 nm (see Fig. 10). The addition of BC to unfilled chitosan films promoted an increase in Young's modulus and a reduction in the elongation at break value, in addition to reasonable thermal stability and low O2 permeability.

sections.heading: 4.5. Catalytic materials
sections.text:
Materials with porous nanostructures are an alternative for the development of heterogeneous catalysts and membranes for separation
processes. In that sense, it is possible to take advantage of their benefits for pollutant abatement in diverse media. Zhang and Qi [208] used BC pellicles dipped in a solution of tetra-n-butyl titanate, acetylacetone, and isopropanol. The resultant material exhibited an enhanced photocatalytic activity in comparison with an isolated titania network. The strategy of synthesis is suitable for other metal composites. Zhou et al. [209] prepared BC nanofibers supported palladium catalyst through 3 h of hydrothermal reduction. The BC/Pd catalyst was highly efficient and recyclable for standard Heck coupling reaction, with improved thermal stability with regard to pure BC, lower weight loss, and preserving the original structure of Pd and BC. Yang et al. [166] reported the employment of crystalline cadmium sulfide (CdS) to fabricate BC/CdS via a hydrothermal reaction between CdCl2 and thiourea. The resultant nanocomposite presented better thermal stability than pure BC. The photocatalyst efficiency was evaluated through the degradation of methyl orange, obtaining an 82% of degradation and good recyclability.

sections.heading: 4.6. Stimuli responsive materials
sections.text: Nanogels are crosslinked polymer gels, based on well-dispersed nanoparticles in an aqueous medium [210]. They present environmental sensitivity, i.e., response to changes in temperature, pH, luminance, chemical, and physical stimuli and other external factors. One of the most investigated thermosensitive nanogels is poly(N-isopropylacrylamide) (PNIPAM) [211]. Halake and Lee [212] used fibers of BC as nanostructures, aligned micropores as microstructures and then performed in situ UV photopolymerization to immobilize both components into a PNIPAMs network. The combination enhanced the volume transition, allowed fast water infiltration (ideal for super absorbent applications) but reduced the elastic modulus. BC whiskers/ poly(N-isopropylacrylamide-co-butyl methacrylate) (PNB) nanogel complexes, designated as BC/PNB, were elaborated in [213] by soapfree emulsion polymerization based on PNIPAM and poly(N-isopropylacrylamide-co-butyl methacrylate) (PNB) nanogels. BC contributed to enhancing the poor mechanical properties of isolated PNB, yielding good biosafety. In addition, the nanomaterial retained the good thermo-sensitivity of PNB, with easy flow at low temperatures and gel formation at high temperatures, being suitable for vascular embolization interventional therapy. On the other hand, the addition of AAc makes hydrogels to become thermo- and pH-responsive. The exposure to electron-beam irradiation of BC and AAc permitted their combination at different doses [137]. The resultant hydrogel presented a macroporous structure, with pore size decreasing when increasing the AAc content and irradiation dose. They were pH-responsive, suggesting a possible application in temperature-controlled delivery.

sections.heading: 4.7. Sensors
sections.text:
The development of BC based sensors has taken advantage of its large specific surface area, the number of surface hydroxyl groups, high water absorption capacity and water holding capacity [214]. BC nanofibers have been used to cover a quartz crystal microbalance (QCM) for the preparation of a humidity sensor. When the humidity of the testing chamber rose, the weight increase of BC was registered. Thus, it was feasible to fabricate a simple, highly stable, sensitive, and low-cost humidity sensor based on BC nanofibrous coated QCM [214]. A similar procedure allowed for preparing a formaldehyde sensor using BC and QCM [215], coating BC with PEI. The hydroxyl groups of BC and the amide groups of PEI permitted the formation of hydrogen bonds. The nanofibrous BC/PEI network was successfully used for the detection of formaldehyde, with PEI acting as the detective material. The sensor exhibited good reversibility, reproducibility and a linear relationship with the increase of formaldehyde concentrations (concentration range of 1–100 ppm at room temperature).
Wang et al. [216] reported a different approach for the preparation
of a BC/Au sensor. They performed the synthesis of gold nanoparticles in a suspension of BC. Heme proteins such as horseradish peroxidase, hemoglobin (Hb) and myoglobin (Mb) were successfully immobilized on the surface of the BC/Au surface. The immobilized heme proteins showed electrocatalytic activities to the reduction of H2O2 in the presence of the mediator hydroquinone (HQ). The amperometric hydrogen peroxide biosensor prepared showed biocatalytic activity with good sensitivity, low detection limit and fast response to hydrogen peroxide. Wang et al. [217] followed a similar procedure to develop a BC/Au glucose biosensor.

sections.heading: 4.8. Membranes for separation processes
sections.text:
The intrinsic properties of BC also give rise to its application as an agent for separation of elements, filtration, dialysis or to favor ions exchange between two composites. Phisalaphong et al. [218] dissolved 3 wt% BC in an aqueous solution made of 4 wt% NaOH and 3wt% urea. Then, the BC slurry was cooled at −5 °C for 12 h, later centrifuged at 10 °C for 30min. The solution was then mixed with a 3 wt% sodium alginate solution and finally coagulated in 5 wt% CaCl2 and 1% HCl solution. Although the mechanical properties of BC-based composite decreased, the degree of swelling in water improved. Since it exhibits a homogeneous nanoporous structure, chemical stability, and water absorption capability, the authors proposed its use for separation processes. He et al. [219] explored the adsorption capacity of BC/silica, built by vacuum infiltration. The material exhibited superelasticity and recyclable compressibility, hydrophobicity with a contact angle of 152°, oil binding capacity of 10 times its weight and an oil-retrieving capacity.
Dubey et al. [220] developed a BC/chitosan membrane in order to obtain the separation of ethanol/water azeotrope (EtOH/H2O). In contrast to the blend of PVA and chitosan (which dissolve at high water concentration), the BC/chitosan membrane remained unchanged. Also, it showed better thermal stability, dimensional stability, and superior mechanical properties. Choi et al. [162] prepared BC/AAc (acrylic acid) nanocomposite membranes with ion-exchange capacities.

sections.heading: 4.9. Food applications
sections.text:
Food industry also takes advantage of BC, since it can form hydrogels with good rheological properties. It is feasible to perform the BC growth medium modification to give flavor, color, texture, and shape to cellulose produced by the bacteria, making it usable in food.
BC is a type of dietary fiber, which offers benefits to the digestive
health and decreases the risk of chronic diseases such as obesity, diabetes, and cardiovascular disease [221]. Similarly, it can be used as an additive to produce low-calorie food. Lin et al. [222] processed BC with an alkali treatment, increasing its water-holding capacity. The resultant composite (designated as alkaline treated-nata) was added to surimi, finding that the BC properties were appropriate for its use as a fat replacement and an additional dietary source. Chau et al. [223] found that the administration of BC to hamsters decreased the concentrations of serum triglyceride, serum total cholesterol, and liver cholesterol, being considered as an alternative for gelatin or similar products. Okiyama et al. [224] have analyzed the effect of BC on the rheology of food. They found that BC, unlike xanthan gum, prevents the precipitation of cocoa in chocolate drinks by trapping it in the microfibrillar mesh, acting as an excellent suspending agent. BC also improved the mechanical properties of pasty condiments by reducing its stickiness. BC can be used as a stabilizer for ice cream since it can be considered similar to the commonly used gum for the same purpose. BC has also been used in tofu body-reinforcement. Tofu's fragility is a big problem for its transportation; however, with a minimum percentage of BC, its mechanical properties improved significantly.
Also, bacterial cellulose has found applications in smart and active packaging. Bacterial cellulose-based edible antimicrobial films were developed using bovine lactoferrin as the active component [225]. These functionalized films reduced the viability of E. coli and S. aureus, and were proposed for being used in direct contact with highly perishable foods. Jipa et al. [226] developed BC based films incorporating sorbic acid (SA) as an antimicrobial agent. Monolayer films, prepared using powdered BC (BCP) and poly(vinyl alcohol) (PVA), were coated with BC membrane to obtain multilayer films. Tests indicated that both SA and BCP concentration influenced sensitivity to water, release rate and antimicrobial ability of mono and multilayer films. Using E. coli - one of the most important pathogens for testing antimicrobial properties of films, they reported a diffusion coefficient for the antimicrobial agent of 10–12m2 cm−1 for monolayer films, being higher than for multilayer ones. Also, the SA concentration and the water solubility of the films influenced the effectiveness of the antimicrobial properties [226].
Kuswandi et al. [227] immobilized methyl red onto a bacterial cellulose membrane by the absorption method, to develop a novel sticker sensor. The relationship between the color change of the sensor and storage time of chicken followed a similar trend, suggesting a possible application for assessing chicken cuts' freshness. Similarly, it was reported that a BC/curcumin membrane responded with visible color changes to volatile amines released during fish spoilage [228] and
that bromophenol blue/bacterial cellulose worked as a color indicator for assessing the freshness state of the guava fruit [229]. In the same line, Pourjavaher et al. [230] developed bacterial cellulose-based pH indicator by immersing the films in an anthocyanins solution extracted from Brassica oleracea. BC-diluted anthocyanins films demonstrated a high pH-responsive behavior when exposed to pH 2–10.

sections.heading: 4.10. Energy storage
sections.text:
The combination of BC with conductive nanomaterials can lead to the development of devices used for energy storage applications. The ability of BC to catalyze the precipitation of palladium generates structures with a high surface area. In that sense, the BC/Pd materials can have applications in electronic devices [231]. BC was found to be suitable for the construction of polyelectrolyte membranes and fuel cell development. Yang et al. [73] used platinum to develop BC/Pt using an in situ chemical-reduction method, obtaining a catalyst with high electrocatalytic activity. By doping the BC films with proton acid, the matrix proton conductivity increases notably, indicating the BC availability to be explored as membrane in fuel cells.
In addition to mechanical strength, the materials used for energy devices should exhibit flexibility for technological applications. Thus, the development of electrically conductive and stretchable membranes is of special interest. Pyrolyzed bacterial cellulose, composed of interwelded ultrathin carbon nanofibrils, can be an alternative to produce a mechanically robust three-dimensional conductive network [232]. Pyrolyzed BC/polydimethylsiloxane pellicles were produced using BC as a precursor. These exhibited an electrical conductivity of 0.2–0.41 S cm−1, maintaining their electromechanical properties when subjected to high tensile and bending strain [233].
Constructing asymmetric supercapacitors based on BC is feasible. Chen et al. [164] developed a supercapacitor by coating BC pellicles with MnO2 (BC/MnO2) to act as the positive electrode and then coating BC with nitrogen to act as the negative electrode using a green approach. The device was reversibly charged/discharged, delivering an energy density of 32.91Wh kg−1 with high cycling stability.

sections.heading: 4.11. Others
sections.text: The cellulose synthesized by the Gluconacetobacter bacteria has been used to develop a model for plant cell walls [234–236]. Furthermore, it is feasible to use BC to study the plant cell expansive growth. Initially, researchers presumed that the plant cells growth occurred due to the presence of a wall loosening agent, but not due to the cellulose network by itself. Based on their work with bacterial cellulose, Torres et al. [237] noticed that the BC network presents certain mechanical properties that offer a satisfactory explanation to the wall stress relaxation phenomena (which gives rise to plant cell growth). They suggested that the wall stress relaxation was determined by the cellulose network itself but not for a wall loosening agent. That is, BC displays reversible stress softening and stress recovery, which is consistent with the behavior of plant cells when growing, since the cells remain unaltered for a given range of internal pressure until reaching a critical threshold, after which they expand. This behavior can also explain the mechanical “safety mechanism” under stress reported for plant and animal cells which preserves their existence [237].

sections.heading: 5. Conclusions and remarks
sections.text:
Bacterial cellulose emerges as a versatile material for future applications in various areas. Its availability, 3-D network structure, excellent mechanical properties, and the ability to host reinforcements to achieve synergistic and superior properties have opened the possibility of more constant and extensive uses.
We have shown how the use of different nanofillers (conducting polymers, metal, graphene, ceramics, and bio-materials of nanometric
dimensions) lead to the improvement of one or several characteristics of BC-based nanocomposites, such as mechanical properties, degradation ratio, water absorption uptake, electrical conductivity, thermal stability, and optical characteristics. Bacterial cellulose presents a nanosized 3-D structure, and some fillers can also have nanometric dimensions. The interaction between these two phases can be described as an interaction between two nanometric supra-molecular structures. The resultant composite can be regarded as an all-nano or nano-nano material.
In addition, many practical procedures can be used to elaborate these all-nano composites. Based on them, this review has proposed a classification that takes into consideration the final state of the BC matrix after the incorporation of the reinforcements. They can be classified into two clearly identifiable clusters: disturbed or undisturbed network methods. The former generally involves the use of a disintegrated BC network or single BC fibrils, which require the incorporation of a second phase to form the composite. The latter keeps intact the original BC matrix, taking advantage of its structural properties and finally blending it with reinforcing nanoparticles. Despite the difference, both methods involve BC interaction with various fillers, as well as reinforcement of synthetic polymers with BC nanofibers. Furthermore, the undisturbed network methods can be sub-classified in turn into bottom-up and top-down approaches. Bottom-up approaches usually consist of making an initial modification to the culture medium of the Acetobacter bacteria, adding the nanoreinforcements. As the 3-D matrix is formed, the nanoparticles will be incorporated automatically. Top-down approaches imply the incorporation of the nanoreinforcements on the bacterial cellulose 3-D matrix already formed, using capillarity or in situ polymerization to absorb them.
BC nanocomposites have found a variety of applications in several areas. Their porosity, nontoxic biocompatibility, water holding capacity, and high strength make them suitable for applications including but not limited to high strength materials, catalytic materials, optical materials, sensors, wound dressing, bone tissue engineering, food applications and energy storage, among others, which were explained in detail in this review. In consequence, BC turns out to be a functional material with advantageous properties already tested for technological and day-to-day applications. The development on a large scale and therefore the generic use of these nano-nano composites is still a pending aspect, and it is expected that due to its low impact on the environment and health, in the midterm it will be a fulfilled objective.

metadata.abstractText: Bacterial cellulose (BC) is a fascinating polymer with a three-dimensional structure formed by nanofibers of pure cellulose, synthesized by some bacteria and organized as a coherent network. Its biocompatibility and remarkable mechanical properties have promoted scientific interest for its use in a variety of applications including biomedical, electrical, among others. However, it is the possibility of incorporating nanosized materials into the coherent 3-D network structure displayed by BC what has propelled multiple investigations on the development of BC nanocomposites for different applications. Here we report the different methods and techniques used so far for the BC nanocomposites production. We have focused on the processing techniques that allow the incorporation of functional nanoreinforcements, nanofillers and additional phases without disturbing the original network structure, leading to the formation of nanomaterials. Processing methods, resulting structure-property relationships and potential applications of these novel nanocomposites are discussed and showcased as a fair example of integrated design and manufacture of materials.
